title: Jessica Rabbit Themed Burlesque Photoshoot Tutorial
summary: Professional photographer Lindsay Adler breaks down her process for creating a cinematic, Jessica Rabbit-inspired burlesque photoshoot. The tutorial covers set design, a multi-light setup using projection attachments and gels, and creative in-camera effects like haze and star filters to simulate a theatrical stage performance.

steps.action: Set up the background using red curtains on C-stands and a dark grey seamless paper background to create depth and a stage-like atmosphere.
steps.tool: Red Curtains, Savage Universal Thunder Gray Background

steps.action: Introduce a haze machine to add texture to the air, which is essential for making beams of light visible.
Position the first light (background light) high behind the subject pointing down. Use a projection attachment with a 19-degree lens and a purple gel to create a concentrated beam of colored light.
Set up the main light using an optical spot modifier to create a hard, crisp circle of light on the subject, simulating a stage spotlight.
Add a fill light using a zoom reflector with a blue gel to lift shadows and mix cool tones with the existing purple and pink palette.
steps.tool: Zoom Reflector, Blue Gel, Profoto Strobe

steps.action: Place a fourth light with a 20-degree grid on the side to rake light across the curtains, adding texture and separation to the background.
Attach a 4-point star filter to the camera lens to create starburst effects from the specular highlights on the model's sequined dress.
Capture the final images using a mirrorless camera and a standard zoom lens.
steps.tool: Canon EOS R5, Canon RF 24-105mm F/4 L IS

key_takeaways: Haze is required to make light beams visible in a photograph.
Hard light sources are necessary to maximize the effect of star filters on reflective materials like rhinestones.
Projection attachments can overheat; shooting at lower power with higher ISO/wider aperture helps manage heat.
Using complementary colored gels (like purple and blue) adds dimension and mood to the scene.
Layering lights (beam, main, fill, background accent) builds a complex, theatrical environment.
